title: M.C. Mehta vs. Union of India (Oleum Gas Leak Case)
summary: Established the principle of 'Absolute Liability' for harm caused by hazardous or inherently dangerous industries, superseding the 'Strict Liability' rule of Rylands v. Fletcher. Emphasized that the enterprise must ensure no harm results and compensation should be correlated to the magnitude and capacity of the enterprise.

title: Vellore Citizens Welfare Forum vs. Union of India
summary: The Supreme Court explicitly incorporated the Precautionary Principle and the Polluter Pays Principle as essential features of Sustainable Development and part of the environmental law of the country. Directed tanneries to pay compensation for environmental damage.

title: Indian Council for Enviro-Legal Action vs. Union of India (Bichhri Village Case / H-Acid Case)
summary: A landmark judgment reinforcing the Polluter Pays Principle. The Court held that industries responsible for large-scale environmental degradation (chemical pollution in this case) are liable to pay for the remediation of the damaged environment and for compensating victims.

title: T.N. Godavarman Thirumulpad vs. Union of India & Ors.
summary: A continuous mandamus case that has profoundly impacted forest governance in India. It expanded the definition of 'forest' to include its dictionary meaning, irrespective of ownership or notification. Led to numerous orders on forest conservation, mining, wood-based industries, and compensatory afforestation (CAMPA).

title: Rural Litigation and Entitlement Kendra, Dehradun vs. State of U.P.
summary: One of the earliest environmental PILs. The Supreme Court ordered the closure of limestone quarries in the Doon Valley, balancing ecological preservation with livelihood concerns. Recognized the right to a healthy environment as part of Article 21 (Right to Life).

title: A.P. Pollution Control Board vs. Prof. M.V. Nayudu
summary: The Supreme Court elaborated on the Precautionary Principle, stating that the onus of proof is on the actor/developer to show that their action is environmentally benign. Emphasized the role of scientific uncertainty in environmental decision-making.

title: M.C. Mehta vs. Kamal Nath & Ors.
summary: This case firmly established the Public Trust Doctrine in Indian environmental jurisprudence. The Supreme Court held that certain resources like rivers, forests, and air are held by the State as a trustee for the free and unimpeded use of the general public.

citation: Indian Council for Enviro-Legal Action vs. Union of India (Bichhri Village / H-Acid Case) AIR 1996 SC 1446

It emphasized the importance of the Forest Rights Act, 2006, and mandated that the consent of the local Gram Sabhas (village councils) of the Dongria Kondh tribe was necessary for any diversion of their traditional forest lands, highlighting the interplay between FCA and FRA.
